catalyst.source: Here the TiO 2 -GCM composite was used as a photocatalyst to convert CO 2 with H 2 O into methane (CH 4 ) under simulated solar irradiation, and the detailed test procedure can be seen in experimental section.
catalyst.context: The structural characteristics of the synthesized TiO 2 -GCM are firstly characterized by XRD.The low-angle XRD pattern in Figure 2a exhibits a broad diffraction peak in the range of 2 1.1-2.0 , which indicates clearly the existence of a disordered mesoporous structure.For the wide-angle XRD pattern (Figure 2b), it can be observed that in addition to the two weak and broad peaks at around 25 and 44 which can be respectively indexed to the (002) and (101) reflections for graphitic carbon, all diffraction peaks can be well indexed to anatase TiO 2 (JCPDS no.21-1272) and no evidence of rutile TiO 2 is detected, suggesting graphitic carbon matrix can stabilize the TiO 2 anatase phase even at elevated temperature high up to 900 C. The crystallite size estimated from the line broadening of the anatase TiO 2 (101) reflection plane (2 25.3 ) according to the Debye-Scherrer equation is about 14 nm.TG result (Figure 3) under air atmosphere exhibits that this TiO 2 -GCM composite has a chemical composition of about 80 wt anatase TiO 2 and 20 wt graphitic carbon. The SEM image in Figure 4b show that the microspherical morphology of the SiO 2 template is replicated in the TiO 2 -GCM composite, the average diameter of the microspherical TiO 2 -GCM is about 0.2 m which is similar to the hard template SiO 2 microspheres (Figure 4a).The detailed structure was provided by TEM images.From the low-magnification image (Figure 5a), it can be seen that besides the microspherical morphology, uniform wormlike mesoporous channels in large domains were clearly observed for TiO 2 -GCM.In addition, low-magnification image (Figure 5a) and the high-magnification TEM (HRTEM) image (Figure 5b) both confirm that anatase TiO 2 nanoparticles with the size of 8-14 nm are well deposited in the graphitic mesoporous carbon.And the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (inset in Figure 5b) confirms that the formed anatase TiO 2 is single-crystalline nature, which is accord with that obtained from XRD analysis.Furthermore, HRTEM image exhibits that the mesoporous carbon support has a relative high graphitic degree with the d spacing of the observed lattice planes of 0.345 nm and very close to the d( 002) value (0.34 nm) of typical graphite, which is in agreement with our previous study. 21igure 6 gives the N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and corresponding pore size distribution curve of TiO 2 -GCM.The isotherm exhibits a typical type-IV curve with a hysteretic loop in a wide relative pressure (P/P 0 ) range of 0. Figure 6.It can be seen that the TiO 2 -GCM composite has a uniform pore size distribution centered at about 3.4 nm which is ascribed to the void spaces between the nanoparticles.The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for TiO 2 -GCM is up to 250.5 m 2 g -1 , such high specific surface area is beneficial to the reactant molecules adsorbed on the surface of the material and make the TiO 2 -GCM composite have important applications in photocatalysis. In order to enhance the efficient photoreduction of CO 2 , the primary task is the development of high efficiency semiconductor photocatalysts. 22Here the TiO 2 -GCM composite was used as a photocatalyst to convert CO 2 with H 2 O into methane (CH 4 ) under simulated solar irradiation, and the detailed test procedure can be seen in experimental section.For comparison, the photocatalytic performance of the commercial Degussa P25 titania was also carried out under the same experimental conditions.Figure 7 shows the time profile of the yields of CH 4 under irradiation of simulated solar, it can be observed that the TiO 2 -GCM composite (CH 4 : 10.3 mol g -1 cat) exhibits much higher photocatalytic activity than commercial TiO 2 (CH 4 : 0.7 mol g -1 cat) when the irradiation time of 300 min. Such pronounced photocatalytic performance can be ascribed to the unique structure of the TiO 2 -GCM composite with a variety of favorable properties.First, monodispersed microspheres with wormlike mesostructure make facile the reactant diffusion into the bulk of catalyst and hence provide fast intraparticle molecular transfer.Second, the high surface area can enhance the light harvesting and the adsorption for reactant molecules.Finally, well-interconnected graphitic carbon matrix has a high electronic conductivity which extends TiO 2 's bandgap to higher wavelengths and suppresses the recombination rate of the photogenerated electron-hole pairs, these seem to be the main reason in our study for the enhancement of the photocatalytic activity of TiO 2 by the combination with graphitic mesoporous carbon.

light source.source: and the resulting composite with hierarchical mesostructure and high specific surface area exhibited exceptionally high activity in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O under simulated solar irradiation.
light source.context: Mesoporous TiO 2 /graphitic carbon microspheres were synthesized by a simple nanocasting route using monodisperse SiO 2 microspheres as the template.X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption-desorption, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscope and thermogravimetric analysis techniques were used to characterize the sample.It was observed that anatase TiO 2 nanoparticles of 8-14 nm in diameter were highly dispersed in the graphitic carbon microspheres, and the resulting composite with hierarchical mesostructure and high specific surface area exhibited exceptionally high activity in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O under simulated solar irradiation.

light source.context: Monodisperse SiO 2 microspheres were prepared by Stober method according to literature. 20A simple nanocasting route was used to synthesize mesoporous TiO 2 /graphitic carbon microspheres.In a typical synthesis, 10 mmol of titanium tetrachloride and 5 g of soybean oil were dissolved into 15 mL of acetone to form a homogenous solution.Then 2.5 g of SiO 2 microspheres was added to above solution and the mixture was stirred for 6-8 hours to evaporate the solvent.The dry powder was calcined at 900 C under Ar flow for 4 hours with a z E-mail: xilifudan.edu.cn;ygwang8136gmail.comheating ramp of 1 C /min to decompose and carbonize the precursors.Finally, the silica template was removed using a 2 M NaOH aqueous solution and this etching process was repeated three times.The resulting composite material is denoted as TiO 2 -GCM. XRD patterns were collected in -2 mode using Rigaku D/Max2rB-II diffractometer (CuK 1 radiation, 1.5406A).SEM images were performed on a Philips XL-30 scanning electron microscope operating at an acceleration voltage of 25 kV.TEM images were done using a JEOL JEM-2010 electron microscope with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV.Nitrogen sorption isotherms were measured at -196 C on a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 apparatus.TG analysis was carried out using a Mettler Toledo TGA-SDTA851 analyzer (Switzerland) from 25 to 800 C in an air flow of 80 mL min -1 at a heating rate of 5 C min -1 . The photocatalytic test was carried out in a stainless steel reactor with the volume of 1500 mL (as shown in Figure 1).Catalyst powder (0.10 g) was dispersed on the stainless steel omentum which was fixed in the center of reactor.The bottom of glass wool support was moisturized with 5.0 g of deionized water to maintain saturated water vapor in the reactor, and a Xe arc lamp (300 W) with sunlike radiation spectrum was put at the top of quartz window with the distance of 8 cm.Prior to illumination, the reactor was first purged with the CO 2 H 2 O mixture at 100 mL min -1 for 2 h to establish an adsorption-desorption balance.After that, the reactor was tightly closed and the Xe lamp was then switched on to start the experiment.The reaction temperature and pressure were maintained at 30 C and 110 KPa, respectively.The gas phase products were taken at various time during the irradiation and analyzed by gas chromatography.
